Human culture has always had a lot to say about birds. But what does that say about us? Paul Evans reports. There's a bumping sound from the greenhouse as a small brown bird hits the glass. It's a wren, a bird often seen as a sign or omen. Is it trying to send a message from the edge of my imagination? Or is it just a bird trapped in a greenhouse? Both could be true, depending on your perspective. Wrens have been part of British culture for a long time. In medieval times, people believed the direction a wren flew could predict their luck. Today, images of wrens are still found in British homes, even if the old beliefs have faded. A forest without wrens feels empty. This is because folklore about birds is deeply rooted in our history, from a time when people relied on nature for survival. As cultures change, so do the meanings we attach to animals. For example, in the early 1500s, red kites were common in London and seen as helpful scavengers. But later, they were considered pests and nearly disappeared, except in Wales. Now, red kites are protected and have become symbols of conservation in Britain. Our connection to birds goes back to early human history. The first birdwatchers observed birds to detect predators, weather changes, and food sources, and also saw them as links to the spiritual world. When we ask why birds matter to us, we're also asking about our own identity. Birds represent flight, song, and freedom, which we admire and envy. Some might say these feelings are outdated, but like the appendix or wisdom teeth, they are still part of us. Birds have become indicators of environmental change. In Britain, 30 bird species are endangered, which is not only a loss of unique birds but also a cultural loss. Birds like the skylark, turtle dove, and lapwing symbolize love and magic. Their decline is felt deeply by those familiar with literature and folklore. However, the loss of birds not featured in stories often goes unnoticed. Folklore is important because it connects us to birds in a way that scientific terms cannot. It evokes feelings and attitudes buried under modern life. Whether watching wildlife films or birds in our gardens, the excitement we feel is hard to explain scientifically. Birds engage us in ways we struggle to understand, and the stories we tell about them help us interpret their messages. The wren in the greenhouse creates a link between the present and a distant past, holding its song as it flies into the future, leaving us with a mystery to ponder.

Maps are used to show the relationships between different points and features on the earth's surface. These relationships are based on distance and direction. In the past, people often measured distance in terms of time, like "a day's journey by river," which told more about how easy it was to travel through an area than the actual distance. Direction was less important for travelers who mainly wanted to know where to go and how far it was. Because of this, written travel guides were popular for a long time, sometimes more so than maps. Even today, some maps, like those of railway systems, might not show true directions accurately. Early maps used signs to show important landmarks, and these signs varied in size to show their importance. The style of these signs depended on the map's purpose and where it was made, so understanding early maps requires knowing the conventions used at the time.
The history of map-making, or cartography, is about improving the accuracy of distance and direction and adding more details to maps. Cartography has used other sciences to help with this. For example, instead of using shadows or stars to find direction, people used the magnetic compass, which allowed for more precise measurements. As people explored more of the world, they tried to map it more accurately. Astronomers found out that the earth is slightly flattened at the poles, which led to more precise mapping of large areas.
Over time, the needs of map users changed. Travelers and merchants were no longer the only ones using maps. Soldiers needed accurate maps for artillery, which required showing the land's surface features accurately. This led to the invention of contour lines. Archaeologists, historians, and modern geographers also had specific needs for maps. Today's cartographers have developed ways to map various distributions, like geological layers and land use. The recognition of maps' value in many sciences has led to a modern revival of cartography.
However, the development of cartography has not been a smooth, continuous process. There have been times of slow progress and times of rapid development. Sometimes old ideas persisted alongside new ones. Cartographers often knew what needed to be done but had to wait for better tools to implement their ideas. Since it was easier to copy old maps, and because of the investment in printing, map publishers were sometimes slow to adopt new ideas. Therefore, maps should not be taken as perfect evidence of the knowledge and techniques of their time. The many maps we have today are the result of much human effort and thought, making them valuable records for studying human history. This is what makes the study of historical cartography so interesting and educational.

TIM RICE
I was invited into a young man's living room, which felt like a calm and cultured space compared to the messy rooms around it where his less ambitious family members spent their time. Moving from the kitchen to his living room felt like going from economy to business class on a flight. This room had the largest collection of records I had ever seen, the first stereo record player and tuner I had encountered, and surprisingly, a teenager who had spent money on Georgian wine glasses, pictures, and furniture. His name was Andrew Lloyd Webber. He had won a scholarship to Magdalen College, Oxford, to study history, and he had nine months before starting. During this time, he wanted to become England's version of the composer Richard Rodgers. My own dreams were just as wild; I wanted to be a pop star for the usual reasons: women, money, and fame. The difference between Andrew and me was that my dreams weren't a matter of life or death, though I can say that now. They might have been if I had failed. So, when Andrew suggested a new crazy ambition for me—to become as famous a lyricist as Oscar Hammerstein—I was open to trying it. This was partly because, within ten minutes of meeting, he played me three tunes he had composed, and I could tell he was very talented. As he confidently played selections from the many shows he had written and produced at school, I was reminded of the best show albums from my parents' LP collection. He needed a new lyricist for the outside world. I didn't have much to impress him with, except for instant praise for his music and a real, released seven-inch single of a song I had written (both words and music) that an unknown pop group had recorded three months earlier, which ended their failing career. We parted, promising to meet again and write something together. I was still more interested in the music charts than in West End theatre, but on the bus back to my flat, I told myself I had just met someone with rare talent and determination, and I would be foolish to miss the chance to work with someone who was clearly going to make a big impact on musical theatre, probably very soon. And even if we didn't succeed in challenging the top musical composers, we could try to compete with the Beatles and Rolling Stones later in the summer. The Everly Brothers had just made a comeback and would need new material. The next day, back at my desk in the office where I was training to become a lawyer, the certainty I had felt about a life in show business with Andrew Lloyd Webber had faded a bit. I would, of course, keep looking at the small ads in Melody Maker for groups needing a vocalist and would write a few more simple songs that wouldn't show the limitations of my voice, but it was still likely that I would eventually pass my exams and become a respectable lawyer by the time I was twenty-five. By then, I would surely have outgrown pop music, as my father confidently predicted I would by the time I was twenty-one. This was worrying—if he was right, I only had a few more months to enjoy it. But in the meantime, I felt I had nothing to lose by seeing Andrew again. It would be fun to see a musical with him and to write lyrics that imitated musical lyricists rather than pop stars. Andrew was a fascinating person who talked about Good Food Guides and Victorian architecture, and he supported the Leyton Orient football team. I wasn't convinced by the idea for a musical he had been working on for the past year, but in 1965, I was rarely convinced about anything. His talent was undeniable, and he claimed to have all the contacts. I was soon back in his living room. The idea was about the life of Dr. Thomas Barnardo, the nineteenth-century philanthropist who founded the orphanages that bear his name. His story was indeed worthy, but it didn't really inspire me. The hero was too perfect, at least in Andrew's version of his life, and the project was unoriginal in both concept and execution, borrowing too much from Lionel Bart's hit show, Oliver. On the other hand, Andrew's belief in the brilliance of his score was infectious and not entirely unjustified. What did I know about musicals? As David Land, who later became my agent for over twenty-five years, memorably (and repeatedly) said, if there's a demand for one hamburger bar on the block, there's room for two. We could be the second hamburger joint. I started working with great enthusiasm, especially on the songs meant to be funny. Andrew outlined the plot, played me the tunes, and often gave me the title as well, most of which had probably been thought up by his former school friend who had already tried. I skipped a day at the solicitor's office, pretending to be sick, to write my first batch of theatrical lyrics. I didn't know it that day, but I had changed careers.

**Climate and Weather**
Climate and weather, mainly created by the air around us, have a big impact on where animals and plants live. Climate can shape the look of landscapes. For example, warm and wet conditions all year allow tropical jungles to grow, which are rich in different species. On the other hand, cold and windy areas have fewer living things. Daily weather patterns, which together form the climate, are caused by large air masses moving and mixing, as the atmosphere is always in motion. Some of this movement is because the air surrounds a spinning Earth, and since air is light, it doesn't move as fast as the Earth. However, the sun is a more important cause of air movement.

'Build it yourself at the UK's first bamboo bike workshop
At the Bamboo Bike Club, run by engineers James Marr and Ian McMillan, you can join a course to build your own custom bamboo bike frame. It's a fun weekend activity in Hackney Wick, east London. On a Saturday morning, the Bamboo Bike Club is buzzing with activity. Bamboo is becoming a popular material for bike construction, with companies like Calfee Design in California and Bamboo Bikes in Yorkshire leading the way. However, these bikes can be expensive, with ready-made frames costing around $2,995 or £1,868.
James and Ian wanted to make bamboo bikes more affordable. They spent years developing their idea in a shed in Brecon, Wales. They realized they didn't just want to sell frames; they wanted to share the experience of making something unique and sustainable. This led to the creation of the Bamboo Bike Club, which is more of a community project than a business. James works with wind turbines, and Ian is a civil engineer, but they run monthly courses where participants can build their own bike frames.
The course teaches you how to select bamboo for strength and form strong joints. You start by assembling the front triangle of the bike with 40 mm diameter bamboo, then move on to the seat and chain assembly. Alloy tubes are used for parts that need extra strength, like the handlebars and wheel forks. The process involves using jigs, power tools, and design blueprints, which can be challenging for those not used to DIY projects. However, James and Ian are there to help and ensure everything is done correctly.
Building the bike yourself is a big part of the appeal, and many participants are engineers. But even if you're not, Ian reassures that mistakes are okay and you can always try again. The bamboo is pre-checked for quality, and you can choose from different styles like plain, black, or mottled bamboo.
On Sunday, the focus is on building the lugs, or wraps, using hemp bindings and epoxy resin to create strong joints. A final polymer coating makes the bike waterproof. Once finished, the bike is ready for wheels, brakes, gears, and other personal touches. These bikes are built to last and are as strong as metal ones. Ian has used his for over a year on a 16-mile commute, and James has tested one off-road for three months without any issues.
Bamboo bikes may look a bit rough compared to professional frames, but they have a unique charm. They are ideal for a relaxed ride rather than racing. I chose a 'Classic English' frame for a smooth, easy-going ride. The bikes are light and absorb vibrations well, making them comfortable to ride. James says the real joy comes when you take the bike on the road. The price for building your own bamboo bike is less than £500, making it an affordable and enjoyable project.'

**Self-help Books**
Dione Reverend was just an editor at Random House in New York when she first saw a manuscript by an unknown pop psychologist, Dr. John Gray. "I took one look at the title and knew it would be a number one bestseller," she says, laughing. She was right. Dr. Gray, who is very understanding, is now a multimillionaire, and Dione Reverend has her own company. Dr. Gray's small book on how to improve communication between men and women is a key part of the growing self-help industry. This industry claims to help Americans who want to improve their lives. It also benefits from these desires, creates many more, and supports the New York publishing world. Britain is learning that this genre can fill shelves with books that are as exaggerated as their covers. However, many self-help books are rejected for being too similar to others or too specialized, which is a relief. Editors are looking for the next big hit, and the writing style is not their main concern. What matters is how marketable the book is. "How promotable is the author? What's the 'hook'? Is it universal enough?" Ms. Reverend lists the key questions and admits, "If someone comes to me with a really catchy title, that's two-thirds of the battle won. You know you can reach people."
**Autobiographies**
There needs to be an unspoken agreement between an autobiographer and the reader that the truth is being told. This agreement is rarely fully kept. There are many reasons why a writer might not tell the whole truth. They might feel too ashamed to share certain actions or thoughts. They might leave out things they think are not important. There are also more complex reasons for not sticking to the truth. The writer might believe that inventing stories can better capture the truth about themselves than sticking strictly to the facts. Or they might decide from the start not to follow the truth at all. They might call their book an autobiography to make readers believe it is true, which helps them tell their story. Some readers might still believe it is true even after finishing the book, thinking they have read a true story when it is actually fiction. This can be done without any intention to deceive.
**Dashiell Hammett's Detective Stories**
Experts on detective stories say this genre became popular because it reflects the conflicts of late 19th and early 20th-century society. A detective story is like a symbolic story. The crime represents human desires like lust or greed, and solving it, at least in traditional stories, shows how a person can fit back into society, calming their lawless desires so society can work smoothly again. In Hammett's unique version, society returns to its previous state, but it is shown to be corrupt and false. The detective and the criminal in Hammett's stories are two sides of the same person. They understand each other and are, in a strange way, comfortable with each other. The private detective is part of both the criminal world and the law. To criminals, he seems too honest, and to the law, he seems too shady. He is both a criminal and a competitor. The private detective's mission is sometimes affected by his feeling of being part of both worlds, and sometimes his desire to punish is stronger because he is worried about this ambiguity.
**Science Writing**
Stephen Jay Gould is considered today's greatest scientific essayist. To talk about his writing and get his advice, I met him at the Grand Hotel, where he was staying while promoting his new book. Neither of us felt very comfortable there. Gould said, "I couldn't write about a place like this: Trollope might, but he knew the culture. Understanding the culture is key to being a successful writer. Science, for example, is its own civilization. Only scientists can effectively present it. If you don't live in the community and don't understand its rules, you are at a disadvantage from the start." One of Gould's principles is to never underestimate the reader. "Make no concessions," he says. "You can simplify the language but must never dilute it. Above all, you cannot simplify the argument. Once readers feel they are being talked down to, your piece is finished."

**Air-conditioning**
At Cannons Gym, a popular spot for City of London workers during lunch, the air feels very cold. To cope with this summer's high temperatures, the gym has used a lot of air-conditioning. At quieter times, it feels as cold as the Arctic. This is an example of how air-conditioning is often overused in modern life. It has become a key part of work and leisure, showing how humans can control or change the climate. However, many buildings with air-conditioning could use other cooling methods. They could use natural light and ventilation and have thicker walls that absorb less heat during the day and release it at night. These simple measures can be very effective and would greatly reduce the need for air-conditioning.
**Sundials**
It's not a coincidence that the start of a new millennium has brought renewed interest in sundials, which measure time based on the sun's position. A hundred years ago, sundials were essential for keeping clocks accurate. As clocks and watches improved, sundials became garden decorations—romantic but outdated in a modern technological age. Now, interest in them is growing again. David Harber, a sundial maker, believes their charm comes from their connection to the planets. He says there's a magical moment when a sundial starts working. They are calm, romantic objects that remind us of our place in the universe.
**Paint Your Own China**
My idea of china-painting came from a visit to an arts and crafts show long ago, where serious-looking older women showed how to paint delicate flowers on a teacup with precise brushstrokes. It was fascinating because each stroke created a perfect petal or leaf. Their hands were steady, and the paint never smudged, suggesting they had either practiced for years or had a natural talent for precision. Remembering this, I wondered who would be brave enough to take a china-painting course. Would beginners show natural artistic skill? In reality, the atmosphere was not intimidating. The students were there to have fun, and even the teacher didn't want to paint petals on teacups as quickly and precisely as I remembered.

Uncle chose a package holiday for Keith and Dawne at a good price: a flight from Gatwick Airport and twelve nights in Venice at the Pensione Concordia. When they went to book the trip, the travel agent mentioned that the other people in their package were a school group learning Italian. However, something went wrong. Either at the travel agency, the check-in desk, or in a computer, a mistake happened. Keith and Dawne ended up in a hotel called the Edelweiss, in Room 212, in Switzerland instead of Venice.
At Gatwick, they gave their tickets to a girl in a yellow-and-red uniform. She checked their details and said everything was fine. On the plane, they were surprised to hear people speaking with North of England accents. Keith thought maybe there was a cancellation or the Italian class was on another plane. They ordered drinks and relaxed.
When they landed, a woman with glasses told everyone to stay together. There was no mention of an overnight stop in their brochure, but Keith thought it was just a stopover. It was almost midnight when they arrived at the hotel, and they were too tired to question it. The next morning, they realized they were supposed to stay there for the whole holiday, and they became worried.
The receptionist told them about the lake and the steamer to Interlaken. Keith calmly explained there was a mistake; they were supposed to be in Venice. The receptionist didn't know about any mistake. Dawne described the travel agent who booked their trip, hoping it would help.
A woman named Mrs. Franks, who they had seen at Gatwick, approached them. Dawne asked if she was in charge because they were in the wrong hotel. Keith explained they must have joined the wrong group. Mrs. Franks explained that many holidays have similar tickets and labels, and it was easy to follow the wrong group.
Keith insisted they were not meant to be in Switzerland. Mrs. Franks said she would check and left them standing there. The receptionist was gone, and they heard typing. Dawne thought Mrs. Franks seemed kind, but Keith was lost in thought, trying to remember everything that happened.
An elderly couple, Mr. and Mrs. Nottage, interrupted Keith's thoughts, saying they had a great night's sleep. Keith and Dawne left the reception area. They didn't mention the irony of ending up on a holiday with elderly people when they wanted to escape the demands of the elderly. Uncle had insisted on this trip, even though they tried to convince him to come with them.

'HE WAS A PEOPLE PERSON American executives are now looking up to the polar explorer Ernest Shackleton as a model for good management. Eluned Price reports. In Britain, most people know who Sir Ernest Shackleton was and have a general idea of his achievements. However, America has only recently discovered him. The Wall Street Journal described Shackleton as 'an Antarctic explorer whose feats went largely unnoticed for most of the 20th century,' which might be an exaggeration. But now, Americans are showing great enthusiasm for him. Biographies and accounts of the Endurance voyage are being produced and are expected to sell quickly. The American Museum of Natural History is organizing a major exhibition, and Columbia Tristar is making a film about Shackleton's life. Some American managers have also started to see Shackleton as a role model. His admirers share stories of his achievements with admiration and draw lessons in leadership and communication from them. They even refer to each other as 'speaking Shackleton.' The determined and resourceful Shackleton, with his reindeer sleeping bag and blubber-stove, has become a model for modern management consultants. Jim MacGregor, the managing partner of Abernathy MacGregor Frank in New York, chose Shackleton as a role model years ago. His firm specializes in 'communication aspects of mergers and acquisitions and corporate crises.' For example, dealing with situations like 'this firm's plant blew up' or 'half the workforce has to go.' While Shackleton once worked in public relations for a Glasgow steelworks, it might be hard to see the connection between surviving on albatross in freezing temperatures and handling a financial crisis. 'Even if a company manages its crises well, it can still cause harm by communicating poorly,' says MacGregor. 'Shackleton is a model for management because of his leadership and communication skills. He had his values in order and was at his best when he and his team had a lot to lose, like their lives. One of Shackleton's most fascinating decisions was to turn back when only 97 miles from the South Pole. That decision showed his credibility for future expeditions: the lives of his men were most important.' This refers to Shackleton's 1908 expedition to the South Pole when, 97 miles short of their goal, with supplies running low and limited time to return to their ship, Shackleton made the brave decision to turn back. In a crisis, says MacGregor, people want to know someone is in charge. While managers today often avoid responsibility, Shackleton was ready to take it on. His 1914 expedition became legendary. His ship, the Endurance, was trapped in ice for nine months and eventually crushed. When it sank, Shackleton told his men, 'we should all eventually reach safety if you continue to do your best and trust me.' From the accounts and diaries kept by his men, it's clear that Shackleton was always in charge. 'Shackleton thought everything through, planned for every possibility, kept his men informed, and sought their opinions,' says MacGregor. 'He was adaptable, willing to let go of losses and start anew. We've developed effective principles here that Shackleton exemplifies. Clients can relate to his story without feeling criticized.' Shackleton believed an explorer needs optimism, physical endurance, and patience. 'One of the hardest things to do in desperate situations is to do nothing, especially in America, where the culture is against letting time solve problems,' says MacGregor. 'If you buy bonds and guess wrong on interest rates, you hold on, and eventually, you'll get your money back. To "fix it" and sell would mean a big loss. Similarly, don't be afraid to change plans if they're not working. If a new product fails, don't keep selling it.' Shackleton led by example. On the return journey from the Endurance, he saw Hurley, the expedition photographer, without gloves. He forced his own gloves on Hurley, saying if he didn't wear them, he would throw them overboard. Someone else remembered him doing the same with a biscuit when they were starving on the 1905 expedition: 'He said he'd leave it in the snow. Millions of pounds couldn't have bought that biscuit.' As Caroline Alexander, author of Endurance, the human account of that expedition, says: 'The public's interest in heroic efforts is growing. Shackleton shows that there is little heroism today. Everything else fades away, and he stands as the true embodiment of the ideals we long for now.'
